conversation.text: Charlie arrives in Tokyo, dead tired and jet-lagged. He can't read any signs and people are reluctant to talk to him so he starts questioning his resolve for this exchange trip. His teacher claimed that the Japanese study English as a compulsory subject but Charlie suspects he was deceived.
I have a feeling that the lady who sold me the train ticket did it out of mercy and to get rid of me because she didn't even take my money.
Charlie looks around, nervous. People stare at him because he's the only foreigner here. He isn't in a tourist destination after all.
Am I even in the right town? Isn't someone supposed to pick me up?
He tries talking to the people nearby and some of them answer something that might be English but he can't understand a word.
Damn, I should have taken that Japanese language preparatory course when they were offering it. All I know are a few generic phrases from anime I've watched.
Suddenly, Charlie gets startled by a cheerful female voice.
Yahooo!
Is yahoo a common greeting here? I thought it's a search engine.
Konnichiwa, are you the person who is supposed to pick me up?
Yep, Hanako desu. Naisu to meet yuu.
At least she speaks English a bit. But what's with those clothes? Is she into that kind of fashion?
My house is quite far from the station, let's take a takushii.
Take what?!
Takushii タクシー

options.option: She wants to see if I did my taxes right?

conversation.text: That was a weird ride. Hanako kept talking but I barely understood half of what she was saying. At least I could see the city.
Tadaima! Take off your shoes here, Charlie.
Right, I almost forgot the Japanese hate when their guests don't change into slippers.
It's quite hot but don't worry, we have eakon.
They have what?!
Eakon エアコン
